section_path: Section I > C. Chapter-Specific Coding Guidelines > 19. Injury, Poisoning, and Certain Other Consequences of External Causes > c. Coding of Traumatic Fractures > 2) Multiple fractures sequencing

content.full_text: Multiple fractures are sequenced in accordance with the severity of the fracture. (Evidence: pg no: 80, L63-L65)
content.summary: Sequencing rule for multiple fractures based on severity assessment (Evidence: pg no: 80, L63-L65)
key_concepts: Severity-based sequencing for multiple fractures (Evidence: pg no: 80, L64-L65)

detailed_rules.rule_text: Multiple fractures are sequenced in accordance with the severity of the fracture (Evidence: pg no: 80, L64-L65)
detailed_rules.explanation: When multiple fractures are present, the most severe fracture should be sequenced first (Evidence: pg no: 80, L64-L65)

workflow_steps: Step 2: Assess severity of each fracture
Step 3: Sequence most severe fracture first
Step 4: Continue sequencing by decreasing severity

coding_scenarios.scenario: Patient with both simple wrist fracture and complex femur fracture
coding_scenarios.documentation_example: Closed wrist fracture and open comminuted femur fracture
step_by_step: Step 2: Assess severity (femur fracture more severe)

correct_coding.rationale: Open comminuted femur fracture is more severe than closed wrist fracture (Evidence: pg no: 80, L64-L65)

incorrect_coding.rationale: Less severe fracture should not be sequenced first
incorrect_coding.common_mistake: Not considering severity when sequencing multiple fractures

best_practices: Always assess relative severity when multiple fractures are present (Evidence: pg no: 80, L64-L65)
common_mistakes: Sequencing fractures by anatomical location rather than severity (Evidence: pg no: 80, L64-L65)
tips: Consider factors like open vs closed, displacement, and complexity (Evidence: pg no: 80, L64-L65)
implementation_notes: Requires clinical judgment to assess severity
clinical_context: Important in trauma and emergency settings
